Posts.Content: May 10, 2011 10:00PM jeanne11 wrote: Cat, I am currently on Taxol.  After completing 12 weeks of weekly Taxol, my scans showed considerable  regression.  So, now I am on a schedule of 3 weeks on and 1 week off.  I just had my 16th dose today.  I have found Taxol to be a fairly easy chemo.  The first six or seven weeks went very smoothly.  The only side effects I experienced were hair loss and very mild fatigue.  The hair loss occured on day 16.  It started coming out in clumps whenever I ran my hands through it.  Around week 6 or 7, I started to experience neuroparthy in my toes.  I also had some bleeding whenever I blew my nose.  I now also have some mild neuropathy in my fingertips and some discoloration in my fingernails.  The neuropathy in my feet comes and goes.  Some days I just have mild tingling in my toes and other days my feet hurt.  I have also started to feel achiness in my hips when going up steps or bending to pick something up. I had a three week break before starting the 3 weeks on/ 1 week off schedule and the neuropathy improved quite a bit by the third week.  I also have gotten some peach fuzz on my head and hope  it continues to grow.  Time will tell. I found when I was on A/C chemo, I was able to predict when I would be feeling bad and when I when I would start to feel better.  I also found the first 6 or 7 weeks of Taxol to be fairly predictable in how my body would respond.  It seems harder for me to predict how I will be feeling now.  There doesn't seem to be any rhyme or reason to the days the neuropathy or fatigue feels worse. The streroids given prior to treatment do give me a burst of energy the day after treatment.  They also cause insomnia the night of treatment.  I have a prescription for Ambien and will often take one the night of treatment.  It also pays to keep some apples and prunes handy as constipation can be a problem. Best of luck.  I hope you find Taxol to be an easy chemo.
Posts.Title: When should I expect the SEs from taxol/avastin cmhartley Lynwaz

Posts.Content: Dec 17, 2010 11:03AM jeanne11 wrote: Thanks for the info Lago.  I am hoping to hear back from Johns Hopkins this afternoon with an appointment date.  I will look through the Castle Connolly report of top doctors.  Looks like there are quite a few listed in a 20 to 30 mile radius from my home.
Posts.Title: Can't determine Her2 status jeanne11 jeanne11

Posts.Content: jeanne11 wrote: I have had four lung biopsies in an attempt to determine Her2 status.  I switched hospitals for the fourth biopsy and just learned that they ran the incorrect tests AGAIN and used up most of the tissue sample.  Has anyone else encountered this level of incompetence/negligence?  Is there anyone from Northern Virginia that is happy with their oncolgist and testing facilities?  I have exhausted all of the AI drugs and need to move onto chemo, but seem to be stuck until Her2 status is determined.  I know doctor names aren't exchanged on this forum, but if there is anyone in northern Virginia with some helpful advice, can you PM me?  It would be much appreciated.  I am trying to set up an appointment with Johns Hopkins, but would also like a good local connection to coordinate treatment. I don't think I can handle seeing my doctor shrug her shoulders one more time.  What has happened to medical professionalism and bedside manner?  I was first diagnosed in 1998 and my Pennsylvania care team was excellant.  I was again diagnosed in 2009, in Virginia, and have come to believe that an internship with the Three Stooges is a requirement for a medical degree in this state.  I'm sorry for the ranting, but I am just feeling so alone in this.  I have lost all confidence in my doctor and don't know where to turn. Dx 5/10/1998, DCIS, 1cm, Stage I, Grade 2, 0/12 nodes, ER+/PR+ Surgery 6/17/1998 Lumpectomy: Left; Lymph node removal: Left, Underarm/Axillary Chemotherapy 6/30/1998 AC Radiation Therapy 9/30/1998 Breast Dx 3/5/2009, DCIS, <1cm, Stage IV, Grade 2, ER+/PR-, HER2- Chemotherapy 1/2/2011 Taxol (paclitaxel) Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Can't determine Her2 status jeanne11 jeanne11

Posts.Content: Dec 16, 2010 06:36PM jeanne11 wrote: Thanks for your post Kelley41.  One of my biopsies came back as borderline, but instead of doing a FISH test, the lab sent the remaining tissue to another lab to confirm the borderline.  The last biopsy had orders to do a FISH, but they ran tests to check for primary lung cancer instead.   It just seems like someone is always falling down on the job.  During my second biopsy, the interventional radiolist asked me what he was biopsing for.  On the third, the doctors and nurses stood around my bed and discussed how the pathology slides should be handled.  And on my fourth, I had to remind my doctor that a FISH test was needed because one of the biopsies came back as borderline.  This is the source of my frustration.  I know we all need to educate ourselves on our condition and options, but should we have to be the driving force over every single medical test, decision, reminding our doctors what is needed?  I am exhausted and frustrated.  Surely, this disease is hard enough without dealing with incompetent medical care.  Yes, I have encountered many compassionate nurses and doctors, but my experiences of late have been bad, very bad.  I just am hoping for some good feedback on a good oncologist and hospital in my area.  The "TOP DOCS" in the Washingtonian just isn't cutting it.
Posts.Title: Can't determine Her2 status jeanne11 jeanne11

Posts.Content: Jan 22, 2010 01:59PM jeanne11 wrote: I was 42.  When I was 37, I had a lot of swelling in my breast.  My doctor also said it was nothing to worry about.  After the second visit, he sent me for a mammogram.  I was told everything was fine.  No one told me that due to my very dense breasts, my mammograms were pretty much unreadable.  When I turned 42, my annual mammogram came back clean.  Three weeks later, I felt a lump that turned out to be 1.75 centimeters in size.  My then gynecologist told me it was nothing to worry about.  I just had a clean mammogram.  I can still remember the nurse who was standing behind him.  Her eyes got huge.  I fretted for three weeks and then insisted on an ultrasound.  When I asked the radiologist how they could have missed a lump that size, she showed me my films and explained due to the density of the breast tissue, the lump couldn't be seen. I have had some really wonderful physicians along the way and some that I have wondered how they ever got through med school.  When I was first diagnosed, I didn't know a whole lot about the disease. At the time, I had one friend that had been diagnosed with it and she was (and still is) doing very well.  However, I am continued to be surprised by how many women don't really know anything about the disease, how young it can strike, that mammograms don't always catch it.  We expect our doctors to always know what tests to order and when to question results, but that doesn't always happen.  One of my doctor's thought I was being a bit paranoid.  He reminded me that when one hears hoof beats, don't look for zebras.  I think we all want the doctor who knows when to look for the zebras.
